intro: Gilia lutea var. rosea, commonly known as the rose-colored gilia, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the Malvaceae family and is characterized by its vibrant, showy flowers that range in color from pink to deep rose. The plant typically grows in dry, open habitats such as grasslands and rocky slopes. Its leaves are lance-shaped and covered in fine hairs, while the stems are erect and often branched. The flowers bloom in summer, attracting pollinators like bees and butterflies.
